brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of the study is to compare the efficacy and tolerance of 6- versus 12-week
      antibiotic therapy in patients with diabetic foot osteomyelitis treated medically.

clinical_study.brief_title: Antibiotic Treatment Duration for Non-Surgically-Treated Diabetic Foot Osteomyelitis

detailed_description.textblock:
The aim of this randomized multicenter clinical study is to compare the efficacy and
      tolerance of 6 versus 12-week antibiotic treatment in patients with diabetic foot
      osteomyelitis treated medically as no equivalent data are currenty available in the
      literature.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  diabetic patients treated non-surgically (i.e. without amputation or resection of the
             infected bone) for an osteomyelitis of the foot complicating a neuropathic foot
             without ischemia of the foot defined as the absence of any pedal pulse. Patients aged
             of 18 years or more were included if they had type 2 diabetes and osteomyelitis of
             the foot (i.e.below the ankle).

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients with gangrene or who require bone resection or amputation when osteomyelitis
             of the foot was diagnosed

clinical_study.keyword: diabetic foot osteomyelitis, antibiotic treatment duration
clinical_study.official_title: Six- Versus Twelve-Week Therapy for Non-Surgically-Treated Diabetic Foot Osteomyelitis: A Multicenter Open-Label Controlled Randomized Study

oversight_info.authority: France: Agence Nationale de Sécurité du Médicament et des produits de santé

primary_outcome.description: Remission was defined as the absence of any sign of infection at the initial or a contiguous site, evaluated at least one year after the end of antibiotic treatment (ie at the end of follow-up), with neither a new infectious episode nor the need for orthopedic surgery of the foot at either of these sites during the treatment and follow-up period.
primary_outcome.measure: Primary outcome measure was the proportion of patients of each group with remission of diabetic foot osteomyelitis at the end of follow-up.
